title: 106_hr4520
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Child and Adult Care Food Program Integrity Act of 2000" and includes a table of contents. The "Child and Adult Care Food Program Integrity Act of 2000" outlines eligibility criteria, approval processes, termination/suspension rules for participating organizations, recovery of funds, limitations on expenses, and technical assistance for fraud prevention. It also includes provisions for statewide projects, programs for at-risk school children, and withholding funds for non-compliance. Sec. 12. Withholding of funds for insufficient training, technical assistance, and monitoring. ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA FOR PARTICIPATING ORGANIZATIONS. Amendment to Section 17(a)(2) of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act includes requirements for participating organizations to employ monitoring personnel for effective oversight of child care centers and day care homes. The amendment to Section 17(a)(2) of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act includes requirements for participating organizations regarding employment policies, responsibilities, and bonding for private institutions applying for participation in the program. The institution must be bonded in accordance with state law, regulation, or policy. SEC. 3. Approval of sponsoring organizations and other requirements. Approval of Sponsoring Organizations under the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to consider tax-exempt status and operational capability. State approval for participation in the program will also assess administrative capability. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act now requires sponsoring organizations to demonstrate administrative capability, business experience, and management plans to operate the program. State approval will also assess if the organization fulfills a need and meets program requirements. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act now mandates periodic unannounced site visits to child care centers and day care homes to prevent fraud and improve program operations. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act now requires scheduled site visits at child care centers and day care homes to prevent fraud and improve program operations. Upon enrollment, parents must receive information about the program and its benefits. The Act requires child care centers and day care homes to provide easily understandable information to parents or guardians. For children already enrolled in the program, this information must be given within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Allowable administrative expenses for sponsoring are also outlined. The Act mandates child care centers to provide clear information to parents. Allowable administrative expenses for sponsoring organizations are specified, with the Secretary developing a list for dissemination. SEC. 4. TERMINATION OR SUSPENSION OF PARTICIPATING ORGANIZATIONS. Section 17(d) of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include procedures for terminating participation of institutions and child care centers that engage in unlawful practices or fail to fulfill agreements with the State agency. The Secretary may require corrective action or immediate suspension of operation for entities posing health or safety threats. Institutions must have a fair hearing before termination from the program. The Secretary maintains a list of participating institutions and child care centers. The Secretary maintains a list of entities, including child care centers and individuals, who have been terminated or disqualified from participating in the program. This list is used by State agencies for approving or renewing applications for program participation. SEC. 5. RECOVERY OF AMOUNTS FROM INSTITUTIONS. Amends the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to allow States to recover funds from institutions engaged in fraud or abuse in the program. Amounts recovered can be paid back over time and cannot come from funds used for meals. Institutions have the right to a fair hearing before any fund recovery decision is made. SEC. 6 amends the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to limit administrative expenses for sponsoring organizations of day care centers to 15% of funds provided, with a waiver option for states if justification is provided. SEC. 7 limits the ability of family or group day care homes to transfer sponsoring organizations. Section 17(f)(3) of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to limit the ability of family or group day care homes to transfer sponsoring organizations more frequently than once a year. The amendment limits family or group day care homes from transferring sponsoring organizations more than once a year for valid reasons determined by the State agency, such as when the current sponsoring organization ceases participation in the program. SEC. 8. REALLOCATION OF AUDIT FUNDS. Section 17(i) of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include provisions for the audit funds. Any unobligated funds allocated to a State shall be returned to the Secretary, who will then reallocate them among States in need. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include provisions for audit funds. States demonstrating a need for the funds must use them for conducting audits of participating institutions. Each State agency receiving funds must submit a report summarizing audit results. The amendments take effect on October 1, 2000, or the date of enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. Technical and training assistance provided by the Secretary for identification and prevention of fraud and abuse under the program. Training to be continuous for State agencies and sponsoring organizations to improve program management.

SEC. 10. Statewide demonstration projects involving private for-profit organizations providing nonresidential day care services. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include statewide demonstration projects in 4 States and 2 other States through a competitive application process. The Secretary of Agriculture may carry out demonstration projects in approved States. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act was amended to include statewide demonstration projects in several States through a competitive application process, starting no earlier than October 1, 2001. SEC. 11. PROGRAM FOR AT-RISK SCHOOL CHILDREN. Section 17(r) of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include meals or supplements, update headings to Meal and supplement, specify one meal and one supplement per child per day, and adjust rates for supplements. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include reimbursement rates for meals and supplements, with limitations on reimbursement for meals served in specific states. Amendment to the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 requires sufficient training, technical assistance, and monitoring for the child and adult care food program under the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act.
